t: Nahum 3
Nineveh’s Downfall
Woe*pn to the city of blood, totally*ln deceitful, full*ln of plunder, never*ln without prey.
The*ln crack of the whip and*ln rumble of the wheel, galloping*ln horse and*ln jolting chariot!
Charging*ln horseman, flashing*ln sword, shining*ln spear; heaps*ln of slain, mounds*ln of corpses, dead*ln bodies without end— they*ln stumble over their dead.
Because*ln of the continual prostitution of the prostitute, the*ln attractive mistress of sorcery, who*ln treats nations and clans like merchandise by*ln her prostitution and sorcery,
I*ln am against you. This*lg is the declaration of the Lord*s of Armies. I*pn will lift your skirts over your face and*ln display your nakedness to nations, your*ln shame to kingdoms.
I*ln will throw filth on you and*ln treat you with contempt; I*ln will make a spectacle of you.
Then*ln all who see you will recoil from you, saying, “Nineveh*ln is devastated; who*ln will show sympathy to her?” Where*ln can I find anyone to comfort you?
Are*pn you better than Thebes that*ln sat along the Nile with*ln water surrounding her, whose*ln rampart was the sea, the*ln river her wall?
Cush*ln and Egypt were her endless source of strength; Put*ln and Libya were among her allies.

Yet*ln she became an exile; she*ln went into captivity. Her*ln children were also dashed to pieces at*ln the head of every street. They*ln cast lots for her dignitaries, and*ln all her nobles were bound in chains.
You*ln also will become drunk; you*ln will hide. You*ln also will seek refuge from the enemy.
All*pn your fortresses are fig trees with*ln figs that ripened first; when*ln shaken, they fall — right*ln into the mouth of the eater!
Look,*pn your troops are like women among you; your*ln land’s city gates are*ln wide open to your enemies. Fire*ln will devour the bars of your gates.
Draw*pn water for the siege; strengthen*ln your fortresses. Step*ln into the clay and tread the mortar; take*ln hold of the brick-mold!
The*ln fire will devour you there; the*ln sword will cut you down. It*ln will devour you like the young locust. Multiply*ln yourselves like the young locust; multiply*ln like the swarming locust!
You*ln have made your merchants more*ln numerous than the stars of the sky. The*ln young locust strips the land and*ln flies away.

Your*ln court officials are like the swarming locust, and*ln your scribes like clouds of locusts, which*ln settle on the walls on a cold day; when*ln the sun rises, they take off, and*ln no one knows where they are.
King*pn of Assyria, your shepherds slumber; your*ln officers sleep. Your*ln people are scattered across the mountains with*ln no one to gather them together.
There*ln is no remedy for your injury; your*ln wound is severe. All*ln who hear the news about you will*ln clap their hands because of you, for*ln who has not experienced your*ln constant cruelty?
